holdings.text: The law of pre-emption imposes a limitation or disability upon the ownership of a property restricting the owner's right of sale and compelling sale to co-sharer or neighbour; benefit and burden run with the land.

anchor.surface_text: The correct legal position seems to be that the law of pre-emption imposes a limitation or disability upon the ownership of a property to the extent that it restricts the owners unfettered right of sale and compels him to sell the property to his co-sharer or neighbour as the case may be. The person who is a co-sharer in the land or owns lands in the vicinity consequently gets an advantage or benefit corresponding to the burden with which the owner of the property is saddled even though it does not amount to an actual interest in the property sold.

holdings.text: When a custom of pre-emption is established by evidence to prevail amongst non-Muslims in a particular locality it must be presumed to be founded on and co-extensive with the Muhammadan Law on that subject unless the contrary is shown.

anchor.surface_text: The correct legal position seems to be that the law of pre-emption imposes a limitation or disability upon the ownership of a property to the extent that it restricts the owners unfettered right of sale and compels him to sell the property to his co-sharer or neighbour as the case may be. The person who is a co-sharer in the land or owns lands in the vicinity consequently gets an advantage or benefit corresponding to the burden with which the owner of the property is saddled even though it does not amount to an actual interest in the property sold.
